Knowledge Point: In terms of \isi{phonological} rules, the only difference between the dialects that I know of concerns \isi{glide formation}. In Manu, \isi{vowel} sequences of /ai/ and /au/ become [ay] and [aw], respectively. Otherwise, \isi{central vowel}s /a, ï/ are \isi{deleted} before immediately following \isi{vowel}s, suggesting that this glide-formation rule in Manu bleeds the \isi{vowel}-\isi{deletion} rule (\sectref{sec:2.5.1}). In Yaul, however, \isi{central vowel} \isi{deletion} occurs unimpeded. Thus, we see contrasts such as those in \REF{ex:mdy:1}.
The two dialects are very similar in terms of \isi{morphology} as well. Like Manu, Yaul exhibits a basic three-way \isi{TAM} distinction in verbal \isi{suffix}es \REF{ex:mdy:2}.
Sentences \REF{ex:mdy:3}, \REF{ex:mdy:4}, and \REF{ex:mdy:5} exemplify \isi{imperfective} verb forms in Yaul.
Content 1: \gsrc Itam ma apa \textbf{mite}. | \gll itam mï-a apa ma=ita-\textbf{e} | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ-INT house 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt ‘Father is building a house.’
Content 2: \gsrc Sïmboy ma ya \textbf{mute}. | \gll sïmboy mï-a ya ma=uta-\textbf{e} | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ-INT coconut 3SG.OBJ=grind-IPFV | \glt ‘The child grinds the coconut.’
Content 3: \gsrc Yeta wokïn mï tïn samola \textbf{masi}. | \gll yeta wokïn mï tïn samola ma=asa-\textbf{i} | \gls man huge 3SG.SUBJ dog small 3SG.OBJ=hit-IPFV | \glt ‘The big man is hitting the small dog.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:mdy:6} and \REF{ex:mdy:7} exemplify \isi{perfective} verb forms in Yaul.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï awaw kambïn \textbf{masapi}. | \gll ndï awaw kambïn ma=asa-\textbf{pi} | \gls 3PL yesterday child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt ‘Yesterday they hit the child.’
Content 2: \gsrc Inam ngata ma \textbf{lipe}. | \gll inam ngata mï-a li-\textbf{pe} | \gls mother grand 3SG.SUBJ-INT die-PFV | \glt ‘The old woman is dead [= has died].’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:mdy:8} and \REF{ex:mdy:9} exemplify \isi{irrealis} verb forms in Yaul.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mawalinda} mï \textbf{sala} ne. | \gll nï ma=wali-\textbf{nda} mï sa-\textbf{la} n-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=hit-IRR 3SG.SUBJ cry-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I’ll hit him and he’ll cry.’
Content 2: \gsrc ɑsi \textbf{kɑndɑ} | \gll asi ka-\textbf{nda} | \gls sit let-IRR | \glt ‘[We] will sit down.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Irregular verb}s (with their associated irregular \isi{TAM} \isi{suffix}es) mostly behave the same in Yaul as they do in Manu. Moreover, the same \isi{suppletive} verbal forms (i.e., for ‘hit’ and ‘go’) are attested. The verbs ka- ‘let’ \REF{ex:mdy:9a} and wo- ‘sleep’ \REF{ex:mdy:9b}, however, do not seem to employ the Manu \isi{irrealis} forms with the \isi{prefix}-like element [la-] (cf. \sectref{sec:4.3}).\footnote{These [la- {\textasciitilde} lo-] forms in Manu may be innovations, perhaps reflecting a \isi{fossilized} form of the archaic \isi{detransitivizing} \isi{prefix} *la- (contemporary Manu na- ‘\textsc{detr}’). Yaul does, however, employ the same possibly related \isi{irrealis} form of ‘eat’ as found in Manu (i.e., ama- ‘eat’, landa ‘eat [\textsc{irr]}’).}

Thus there is often apparent \isi{homophony} between the forms una(n) \textsc{‘1pl.incl’} and una(wa) \textsc{‘2pl-int’} and between nguna(n) \textsc{‘1du.incl}’ and nguna(wa) \linebreak \textsc{‘2du-int’}. Furthermore, the distinction between subject and non-subject forms, generally only observable in \textsc{3sg} forms, is mostly eroded in Yaul, since the subject form /mï/ is frequently pronounced [ma] (< /mï-a/), thereby becoming \isi{homophonous} with the non-subject form /ma/. However, the distinction seems to be partially maintained in the \textsc{3du}, where the non-subject form has the \isi{allomorph} [mini=] when immediately preceding /n-/. In fact, in Yaul, as opposed to in Manu, /l-/ conditions this \isi{allomorphy} as well as /n-/, as illustrated by \REF{ex:mdy:10}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itam ma num nini \textbf{minilope}. | \gll itam mï-a num nini \textbf{mini}=lo-pe | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ-INT canoe two 3DU.OBJ=cut-PFV | \glt ‘Father carved two canoes.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:mdy:10} also exhibits the use of the \isi{intensive} \isi{suffix} -a ‘\textsc{int}’ on \isi{subject marker}s, which is common in Yaul.
Content 1: \gsrc Itam ma num nini \textbf{minilope}. | \gll itam mï-a num nini \textbf{mini}=lo-pe | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ-INT canoe two 3DU.OBJ=cut-PFV | \glt ‘Father carved two canoes.’

Knowledge Point: While \isi{periphrastic} ‘going’ \isi{verb phrase}s are not attested in Yaul, it is very common for \isi{future}-\isi{time} sentences to employ what appears to be a \isi{volitive}/\isi{conative} \isi{auxiliary verb} ne {\textasciitilde} ni ‘want, will, try’, as in examples \REF{ex:mdy:12} through \REF{ex:mdy:15}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï uwïl la tanda \textbf{ne}. | \gll nï u=wïl la-ta-nda \textbf{n-e} | \gls 1SG 2SG=with DETR-say-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I want to speak with you.’
Content 2: \gsrc Na umbe wo mana \textbf{ne}. | \gll nï-a umbe wo ma-na \textbf{n-e} | \gls 1SG-INT tomorrow village go-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I want to go to the village tomorrow.’\footnote{It should be observed that the Yaul \isi{irrealis} form of ‘go’

Knowledge Point: \glt ‘I’ll see you tomorrow.’\footnote{In example \REF{ex:mdy:14} we see a reduction of nïmndï ‘eye’ to [indï], which seems to occur commonly in Yaul when this word is used as part of a \isi{discontinuous} verb construction.} [elicited]
Content 1: \gsrc Na umbe indï wandïla \textbf{ne}. | \gll nï-a umbe indï u=andï-la \textbf{n-e} | \gls 1SG-INT tomorrow eye 2SG=see-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I’ll see you tomorrow.’\footnote{In example \REF{ex:mdy:14} we see a reduction of nïmndï ‘eye’

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:mdy:8}, which features the \is{volitionality} non-volitional verb ‘cry’, the \isi{auxiliary} ne ‘want, will, try’ seems to have little or no \isi{volitive} or \isi{conative} force, presumably simply indicating futurity or \isi{potentiality}. Example \REF{ex:mdy:12} additionally shows the use of the \isi{detransitivizing} \isi{prefix} la- ‘\textsc{detr’}, the expected \isi{cognate} of Manu na- ‘\textsc{detr’}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mawalinda} mï \textbf{sala} ne. | \gll nï ma=wali-\textbf{nda} mï sa-\textbf{la} n-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=hit-IRR 3SG.SUBJ cry-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I’ll hit him and he’ll cry.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï uwïl la tanda \textbf{ne}. | \gll nï u=wïl la-ta-nda \textbf{n-e} | \gls 1SG 2SG=with DETR-say-IRR want-IPFV | \glt ‘I want to speak with you.’

Knowledge Point: As in Manu, ‘giving’ constructions are formed with two clauses, the first containing the verb tï- ‘take’, the second containing the verb na- ‘give’, as in \REF{ex:mdy:15a}.
Content 1: \gsrc Yana mï ya \textbf{matï} numon \textbf{manane}. | \gll yana mï ya ma=\textbf{tï} numon ma=\textbf{na-ne} | \gls woman 3SG.SUBJ coconut 3SG.OBJ=take husband 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV | \glt ‘The woman gave the coconut to [her] husband.’

Knowledge Point: Oblique marking \is{oblique marker} works the same in Yaul as in Manu (\sectref{sec:11.4}). Moreover, the form of the marker is =n ‘\textsc{obl}’, suggesting that the \ili{Pre-Ulwa} form was *=n, as opposed to \textsuperscript{†}/=l/. An example of \isi{oblique} marking in Yaul is given in \REF{ex:mdy:16}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itam mala \textbf{man} namndï mase. | \gll itam mala ma=\textbf{n} namndï ma=asa-e | \gls father spear 3SG.OBJ=OBL pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-IPFV | \glt ‘Father shoots the pig with the spear.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Question}s and \isi{command}s are formulated the same in Yaul as in Manu (\sectref{sec:13.1}, \sectref{sec:13.2}). \isi{Negation} likewise occurs with a \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg}’, which follows the subject. Discontinuous \isi{negative} constructions are also possible, namely when \is{negation} negating \is{non-verbal predication} non-verbal \isi{predicate}s. The final element is, as in Manu, me ‘\textsc{neg}’, as seen in \REF{ex:mdy:17}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{ango} yana \textbf{me}. | \gll mï \textbf{ango} yana \textbf{me} | \gls 3SG.SUBJ NEG woman NEG | \glt ‘He is not a woman.’

Knowledge Point: Interesting, \citet{Laycock1971a} records a \isi{non-verbal negator} <meko>, which reflects the opposite ordering of morphemes as found in the Manu \isi{non-verbal negator} ko-me ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\sectref{sec:13.3.1}) \REF{ex:mdy:18}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{ɑŋɡwɔ} nindʒi \textbf{meko} | \gll \textbf{ango} nï-nji \textbf{me-ko} | \gls NEG 1SG-POSS NEG-just | \glt ‘[It] is not mine.’

Knowledge Point: \citet{Laycock1971a} also records <ko> alone as an occasional postverbal element, namely in \isi{negative} \isi{declarative} sentences, such as \REF{ex:mdy:19} and \REF{ex:mdy:20}.
Content 1: \gsrc nɑ \textbf{ŋɡɔ} mundə ɑmɑpɛ \textbf{ko} | \gll nï \textbf{ango} mundï ama-pe \textbf{ko} | \gls 1SG NEG food eat-PFV NEG | \glt ‘I have not eaten.’
Content 2: \gsrc nɑ \textbf{ŋɡwɔ} kəkɑl mɑƀɑli \textbf{ko} | \gll nï \textbf{ango} kïkal ma=wala-i \textbf{ko} | \gls 1SG NEG ear 3SG.OBJ=feel-IPFV NEG | \glt ‘I do not hear it.’

Knowledge Point: In my own notes, I have one example of the \isi{negator} ko ‘\textsc{neg}’ occurring optionally in a \isi{negative command} \REF{ex:mdy:21}. I have not found any equivalent of Manu wana ‘\textsc{proh}’ being used in Yaul.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{ango} malanda ne (\textbf{ko}). | \gll u \textbf{ango} ma=la-nda n-e (\textbf{ko}) | \gls 2SG NEG 3SG=eat-IRR want-IPFV (NEG) | \glt ‘Do not eat it!’
